awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Ultrasound, Oxide, and Oxygen: Microscale Mechanisms for Next-generation Alloy Casting
awd_abstract_narration:
More than 90 percent of U.S. manufactured goods contain cast metal components made with a process involving multiple steps, which include melting of the original metal, and solidification in casts. The commercial viability and energy efficiency of the entire operation require controlling and predicting product quality while maximizing the rate of casting. Unfortunately, measuring the properties of the melt during processing is difficult, and to date quality tests occur only after solidification. This award supports research aimed at providing a new tool to evaluate the melt properties using sound waves at very high frequency (ultrasound). The anticipated results are expected to enable real-time monitoring of the casting process, and lead to new processing methods that will increase the energy efficiency of casting.
 
In metal casting, precise control of the melt properties prior to solidification can be achieved after identifying and characterizing features like grains, inclusions, and bubbles. Ultrasound metrology could track those features, while also imaging solidification fronts and measuring melt flow. Unfortunately, prior implementations of ultrasound in liquid metal have often been unreliable and intermittent. The physical mechanisms impeding ultrasound metrology are not understood. This collaborative project will couple advanced physical and chemical science to enable real-time imaging and flow measurement via ultrasound metrology, before solidification. Combining electrochemical and ultrasound techniques for melt measurements, the project will determine the microscale mechanisms of interaction among ultrasound, metal, oxide, and dissolved gas in order to enable the further development of real-time monitoring of molten metal properties.

por.por_cntn:
This collaborative project set out to enable real-time imaging and flow measurement in liquid metals, especially during casting, using ultrasound. Though ultrasound has been used in liquid metals before, it has been unreliable because of poor understanding of what mechanisms produce the echoes on which ultrasound measurements depend. Pure fluid makes no echoes, and common impurities are too small to cause echoes via specular reflection, so we wanted to determine which impurities cause echoes, and how. We also set out to  provide students an open, inclusive opportunity to advance their careers by doing materials engineering research, to engage undergraduates with hands-on ultrasound experiments in the classroom, and to reach broader audiences through regular seminars.

Intellectual Merit: We explored the microscale mechanisms of ultrasound echo in liquid metal using multiple experimental techniques. We measured echo directly, in lead-bismuth alloy and in gallium and in water, using an ultrasound instrument. We measured flow velocity via ultrasound in the same fluids. We measured the size of impurity particles, after the metal had solidified, using scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and measured their composition using energy-dispersive x-ray spectroscopy (EDS). To estimate the size of impurity particles in the liquid metal, we measured their free-fall speed with the ultrasound instrument, then calculated their size by balancing gravitational forces with viscous forces. Our measurements showed larger impurities in liquid metal than in solid metal, suggesting that clumped particles separate when the metal freezes. We believe those clumps to be the main source of echoes. We had wondered if bubbles might be forming on impurities, then causing echoes, but our measurements with a hydrophone showed no sign of the typical sounds of bubble collapse.

Because liquid metals are typically hot and corrosive, ultrasound probes are often set up to transmit and receive sound through a vessel wall. We characterized many common engineering materials to determine which are best for vessels to contain liquid gallium. We found that acrylic is an excellent choice. We also found that theoretical calculations of sound transmission, based on the acoustic impedance of the probe, vessel, and metal, do not accurately predict signal strength. Better predictions come from measuring how well gallium wets the vessel material, quantified via contact angle. Poor wetting leaves a gap between the vessel wall and gallium that severely reduces signal strength. We found that roughening the vessel wall improves wetting by water but worsens wetting by gallium, so for metals, smooth walls are essential.

Broader Impacts: We mentored a student design team doing experiments to determine how impurities and casting protocols affected the microscopic structure of aluminum parts. We hosted seminars relevant to casting. One PhD student and two undergraduates developed their research and scientific skills as part of the project.
